review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: The pro staff is amazing to work with
cons: No cons I can say

pros: It is a wonderful campus with many bright and talented people working there
cons: Administration has one goal- Profit. This has lead to serious cuts across the board (both positions and salaries), students being offered non competitive and very low financial aide packages, and overall low morale. Admin salaries are through the roof but when budget problems emerge (and those are often and caused by the very admin lining their pockets) the faculty and staff see the cuts. These cuts came after a outside consulting firm revealed one of the biggest problems the university had was its low pay of it's faculty which was nearly 10% lower than other institutions and over 20% less than the other DC colleges. Since 2010 the faculty and staff salaries have barely outpaced inflation, where the top administration has seen their salaries increase by 87% in the same time frame. This tells you all you need to know about how those who run the school approach to salaries.

review_title: Use as a platform to a better job
pros: Great colleagues and retirement benefits, though health care coverage is not generous
cons: Hierarchical, chauvinistic, below market pay

job_title: Sr Financial Aid Counselor in Washington, DC
pros: Off during the holidays. Flexible schedule
cons: No bonuses or pay increases. Everyone at the university regardless of title do not make market rate and haven’t for over 6 years.

job_title: Events and Conferences Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: high paying for CUA jobs
cons: stressful when there's an event

review_title: Would never recommend working here to others
pros: Lots of holiday time off. Pretty location. Easily accessible by Metro.
cons: Poor leadership. Minimal career advancement options. Little to no professional development opportunities. Pay scale decidedly below industry benchmarks. Flat rate salary cut during pandemic rather than considering reasonable percentages based on salary ranges.

job_title: HR Business Operations Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great atmosphere, great compensation and growth potential
cons: Higher education culture is very different from typical corporation culture. So if you are a veteran of HRIS in a corporation setting with advanced automation, just know that process improvement is slow and steady, but there is always room for growth.

review_title: Not a Place I Would Choose Again
pros: Very stable; little pressure to perform.
cons: No real interest in changing what has been done for decades; opaque, disengaged, and borderline deceptive leadership at the school level; terrible record regarding people of color.

pros: Well balanced well balanced well balanced

review_title: I guess it strongly depends on your advisor
pros: Science has its benefits and one of them in my point of view is a work-life balance. PostDoc position is often a good transition towards a professor, staff or an industry position.
cons:
My friend is a truck driver with high school education and he makes three times more than me after contributing 7 years of my life towards a PhD degree. 

All I'm trying to say is - don't stick to a PostDoc position for too long. Value yourself.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Washington, DC
pros: At CUA there is a great, supportive faculty
cons: The administration cares least of all about its workers, and especially its graduate student workers. They do not increase stipends from year to year, so, effectively you take a paycut every year you remain in the program. They cut the healthcare stipend for some graduate students a few years back. They hike up fees, and make you pay them before you ever get a paycheck. Most importantly, they delay the first paycheck received every semester, so if you move across the country, pay first and last month's rent on an apartment, pay security deposit, and pay CUA's graduate fees, know that you won't be getting your first paycheck from them for four to six weeks.

review_title: Get the experience but don’t linger
pros: Job itself is not hard. You can learn a variety of useful skills but management style will vary from department to department. I was lucky to have great supervisors. Unfortunately though, it’s easy to grow stagnant. Many silly obstacles the university doesn’t seem to want to overcome and compensation is not very competitive. Not a place to settle in with your career if you’re trying to advance yourself.
cons: Lack of interdepartmental communication, lots of people wearing way too many hats, no investment in staff, against work from home culture

cons: But if you are an adjunct or grad student, the university itself absolutely does not and will never value you or your labor.

review_title: It could be such a wonderful place
pros: Catholic U. has a wonderful location and campus. In general, faculty are devoted to their students, pay attention to their individual needs and, mostly, students develop their skills and talents greatly. Incoming students are of all sorts, but the education they receive makes the average ones good, the good ones great, and the great ones excellent. Teaching at Catholic is a rewarding experience.
cons: Here's unfortunately where Catholic lags way behind. Teaching resources are limited, research is not supported but required, service weights highly in your load because supporting staff has been leaving/let go  for several years now. Faculty and staff salaries are mid to low and have no relationship with the very high salaries of the upper administration. And this last item is probably the sad thing about Catholic U., the upper administration shows poor competence and very poor management, which is likely the origin of most of the cons mentioned here. Criticism from faculty and staff, even constructive criticism, is ignored with arrogance by the administration, which railroads their plans even as they they fail to make sense to anyone's eyes.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Washington, DC
pros: Good vacation and retirement benefits
cons: Very poor health and dental benefits

review_title: I was the Editorial Assistant in the Public Affairs Office at Catholic University.  I learned a lot about writing as a j
pros: Learned a lot, and was given many hands on projects of my own to do.  Very good if looking into a journalism career in the future! This position was part time and also paid which was great for being able to work multiple jobs to not only earn experience within a field, but also earn money over the summer.
cons: A lot of writing involved, most of which was not incredibly exciting.  I enjoyed the program a lot, however realized journalism was not my thing.  The job could sometimes get redundant a bit boring.

review_title: Wonderful institution, unfortunately currently leadership stinks
pros: Have worked at CUA for almost 2 decades. CUA is a nice small community with wonderful students, staff, and faculty. Most everyone cares for the institution which is truly a gem amongst DC universities. Beautiful campus. Serene.
cons: Unfortunately, the president and upper administration don't really know what they're doing and are really driving the institution into a downward spiral. Times are tough everywhere, but the leadership doesn't really have a clue how to get the institution moving forward. With a little vision and strategic planning, it wouldn't take much to move things in the right direction.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: CUA has a beautiful campus and many career opportunities due to the location.
cons:
The amount of unprofessional staff members on campus can be quite appalling at times.  Even as an employee interacting with upper management daily. 
The University can not balance their budget, which has left many employees and departments in question with future progress. Some departments have even been cut with some long term Professors being offered ultimatums. 
Again, money is being poured into the wrong spots.
High turnover for staff. In my department alone I have seen 6 people leave in the matter of seven months. When students often come in asking why they're always seeing a new face for an advisor, staff members are told by management to make up a reason why that person left.

review_title: Beautiful University, Vibrant Location, Poor Leadership
pros: Beautiful university located in vibrant Washington DC. Brookland is under-going a renaissance with re-development all-around. Small, liberal arts university with outstanding faculty committed to student-learning and development.
cons: Due to poor leadership, CUA has lost its way, changing from a close-knit community of scholars, faculty and students, to one where everyone is seen as widgets, replaceable and part of the "academic machinery." Administrative leadership has failed to articulate a vision for the university after nearly 8 years. There seems to be no strategic planning effort.

pros: Opportunity to learn interact on the job. I work with Tech. experts so the environment can get really serious quickly. There are some busy days which I like as the day not only goes faster but there is the opportunity to exercise my brain power/sharpening my multitastking skills
cons: I found this job through a temp agency and as such my pay is seriously reduced/eaten into by the agency; that in itself can be very discouraging on all levels. When I got the job I was informed it was an administrative position but my job involves some finance, working with budget books, reviewing accounts. There is really not much admin involved- hence why I termed position Finance Coordinator or Administrative Coordinator II/III (I dont know)

review_title: Great environment, not the best pay
pros:
plenty of days off, including long Christmas/Easter breaks. Other Catholic holidays off, and most of the federal holidays too. 1/2 days Fridays in the summer, and of course a generous annual and sick leave policy. excellent 401K match, but you have to wait a year for it to kick in, and have to be at least 26 years old for it. 
everyone on campus is friendly, and generally easy to work with.
cons: there is always stuff "behind the scene" that seems to be going on, so you get the sense of a lack of transparency. also, the pay could improve by ALOT! the health insurance need to be looked into too!

pros: The time off benefit, for exempt staff, is great. Tuition benefit for employee and dependents is excellent, the retirement is excellent.
cons: The HR staff needs major improvements in all areas, benefits, recruitment, and compensation. There are many good employees in these units but they are over worked and underpaid. The hard work they do goes unrewarded. Management in HR  is consistently negative, giving very little support to employees. The atmosphere is extremely unprofessional and there is a very visible in-group and out-group. Managers and faculty take advantage of the the dysfunction in HR by going straight to the Provost or to the AVP of Finance to get what they want. This leave HR in a position of being very ineffective.

review_title: If you're upright and have integrity, don't work here!
pros: It's a beautiful campus filled with lush trees, gardens, and rolling green spaces, but it's a "whited sepulcher."
cons: The administration is based on elitism, hypocrisy, and a "good 'ol boy" mentality. Never mind that it's Catholic; some of the worst hypocrites grace this place and give the Catholic Church a bad name. The HR department operates on nepotism and who-you-know, and if you don't look like what they want, no matter how qualified you are, you will not be considered. Liars and cheats, most of them! And the good ones get out fast.

pros: Decent benefits, great coworkers who genuinely care about their work, students and faculty.
cons:
Seriously underpaid (especially for DC), leaving many low-end employees to live paycheck to paycheck.  Top-heavy administration.  Recent layoffs has killed any joy for the job (especially for the future) which was followed by several new vice-provost position hires.  Makes you wonder how many admins had to get sacked to pay their salaries...
Seriously bad people in charge.  Shadow council that runs the university which makes decisions without any input from faculty nor staff.
University waits for union contracts to expire before sacking everyone the union previously protected then outsources.  Very un-Catholic.

review_title: If you are about to retire and have no desire to advance in your career path, this is the place for you
pros: Beautiful campus/landscaping, managers and staff members are pleasant to work with. Generous vacation and holidays, low-stress job.
cons: The IT department had gone through horrible restructuring and reorganization that resulted in massive layoffs and resignation. Generally staff are treated as a second class citizens and the pay for staff is really low. Due to some financial predicament in the past few years, salary for mid and low level staff has remained static. Some of the senior level staff are over paid.

review_title: CUA is an okay institution if you're okay with being oppressed-by professors and staff- and not using your own thoughts!
pros: Most managers at Catholic are so nice and pleasant to work with. The scene is absolutely stunning with beautiful old buildings, centenary trees, green grass and flowers everywhere.
cons: The administration doesn't care at all about your working conditions. usually the salary is a joke unless you have a more senior position. It's usually very cold there dying the winter. They don't like to turn on the heat.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bethesda, MD
pros: Very laid back, students are engaged and it is fun to work with them. Most of the new labs are very well written and the lab periods go smoothly.
cons: Some of the lab equipment is very old and there is not enough of it, and the labs are very small. Hopefully Mahoney Hall can be fixed up for Chemistry again someday.

review_title: My Experience with CUA as both graduate student and work study
pros: There is a variety of job opportunities on campus for undergraduate and graduate students who want to earn extra money while attending the university.
cons: The communication around the school is often lacking especially between departments.

review_title: CUA is a developing institution where skills, ability, and talent are recognized and appreciated.
pros: CUA has a tight-knit community, healthy benefits, a great location, opportunities for service and development, and much more.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are dependent on either institutional expansion or someone vacating a position, the demands of the ecclesiastical affiliation are occasionally off-putting, and the degree of siloing and student life vs. academic tension are high.

job_title: Legal Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Flexible hours and the professors for whom you work are incredibly kind and understanding. The work is time consuming, but worthwhile.
cons: The number of hours one can work in a week is restricted. Keeping hours is disorderly and done by pen and paper which can often times be cumbersome when an electronic system would provide better organization for both the school and employee.

job_title: Athletic Trainer, Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Great athletes and coaching staff to work with.  They understand staffing difficulties and generally try to keep you up to date on schedule changes.
cons: Salary is very poor for living in the area (DC).  Generally hours are light but they are during inconvenient times.  Typically working second or third shift times but pay does not reflect that.

review_title: Lack of leadership in a small community
pros: So many days off with pay. Half day Fridays during the summer. DC location. Beautiful campus.nice retirement package.
cons: Pay. No raises for the past two years. Directors that don't know how to manage, saying things like "I don't need to know what you do to manage you.". NO checks and balances within the leadership and their spending, meanwhile jobs are being cut and a president who is not in-touch with reality. High employment turnover rate.

pros: Established institution, tuition waived for full-time staff, weeks of annual paid time off
cons: Lower pay compared to similar positions at other universities, no raises planned, job vacancies forced to stay vacant due to budget cuts

job_title: Assistant News Editor in Bloomfield, NJ
pros: The professional staff in the Office of Housing Services is amazing! They are flexible, understanding, and conscious of the fact that your are a student worker, meaning school comes first. The office environment is always interesting with people walking in and out.
cons: The location for office assistants is in the lobby of a residence hall and can get rather chilly in the winter.

pros: Has all the benefits from a small university with the advantages to function as a large one due to location.
cons: Much of the lower administration has a poor work ethic.  Since it is a private institute, money is always an issue.

review_title: Smaller, Agile Organization, Offering Plenty of Opportunities to Develop New Technical Skills
job_title: Tech Services Employee in Washington, DC
pros:
Great community and team-oriented environment with excellent vacation, retirement, and educational benefits.

Leadership at every level is very approachable and committed to modernizing all IT service offerings.
cons: Some challenges inherent with transitional phase require buy-in from long-term employees and patience from new-hires.

pros: Good for a student that does not care much about long term and just wants some quick cash. They will hire ANYONE who says they want a job and goes through the interview process.
cons: The management is some of the most lax I have ever seen. Not punishing those who don't show up for shifts, not giving enough hours to those who do. Terrible.

job_title: Certified Student Attorney in Washington, DC
pros: You get very hands-on experience, learning how to work with clients, manage your own caseload, and determine the best legal strategy to assist your clients. You also get to learn about taxes while working with very enthusiastic people.
cons: The caseload can be heavy (for a young student) and the learning curve is steep at the beginning.

pros: Friendly, hostile free work environment “Also everyone  is a team player.
cons: I really don’t have anything to say about the CONS”because I like working  and  enjoy working at “Catholic University.

pros: Beautiful campus, convenient Metro access, mission-driven university staffed with talented and collegial professionals. In most respects, a lovely place to work, but it can be a misfit if you are not at least respectful of the Catholic faith, whether you practice it or not.
cons: Pay not competitive with other DC area academic institutions. Struggling with maintaining healthy enrollment.

review_title: Great organization to be a part o
pros: Great organization to be a part of.. fosters an environment conducive to learning. Allows adjuncts to think outside of the box and have complete control of subject matter.
cons: Compensation structure could be better, personal growth depends completely on you - whether or not you want to put in the extra work.

pros: the campus is really nice
cons: no one takes responsibility or ownership of anything. no one knows what's going on.

review_title: Several paid holidays , lux environment but few advancement opportunities
pros: Several paid holidays, you can take 4 classes each academic year and the campus is beautiful
cons:
Few opportunities for advancement,there is not enough room to grow. 
Salary is low compared to the cost of living in DC

pros: Easy job, great working environment. They are also really understanding if you have class conflicts, etc.
cons:
There's a lot of turnover, so it's difficult to find a manager to file complaints/seek improvement because it's a bit chaotic.

It can also get a little repetitive.

review_title: Working at Catholic University was an incredible experience.
pros: The office culture at CUA is professional; however, the people that work there are interested in the whole person, not just a numbered-employee. I felt as though I was a person, not an object.
cons: The work-life balance in my job was often challenging.

review_title: Student and graduate of the Catholic University
pros: The location is great right on the DC metro just a few stops from the center of DC
cons: Some of the educators are unexperienced and not helpful.

pros: Had a terrific holiday schedule, and my compensation was more than fair for the level of work.
cons: Health policies follow Catholic doctrine (obviously not surprising, but was a con for me). Definitely would see double the bureaucracy with both church hierarchy and academic hierarchy were involved in decisions.

pros:
- Forms relationships with faculty
- Paid position
- Get to meet so many students
cons:
- Workload varies between professors
- Response time can be slow
- Max of 6 paid hrs/week

review_title: You work in a family-oriented community.
pros: Vacation Time!  4 weeks annual leave plus paid holidays.  At least 1.5 weeks off for Christmas holiday!
cons: Low salary, not comparable to cost of living in D.C. area.  May have to take part-time job.

job_title: Associate Director of Admissions in Washington, DC
pros: Terrific benefits. 21 days off not including school holidays. 10% of salary match for Tiaa-Creff
cons: Management in transition. Poor communication. Little chance for advancement

review_title: Teaching Assistant in Arts and Sciences
pros: Teaching Experience and Community, tuition waived FOR NOW
cons: This employer doesn't pay nearly enough to live on in Washington, DC. And CUA tells you that's how it's supposed to be because you're not an 'employee' but an 'apprentice'. Don't worry about making enough for rent or food because there's always the afterlife.

pros: Great people, good students. Dorm life improving little by little. Changes on South side of campus should help.
cons: Bad upper management at the time, 2011. Some of the deans were not involved as they should be.

pros: Great community family atmosphere, great for those working here and who apply in house it is easier chance to get a position
cons: Need to reboot the technology services

review_title: GREAT PLACE TO WORK AND GREAT BENEFITS FOR SCHOOLING AS WELL
job_title: University Center Employee- Middle Management in Washington, DC
pros: The environment is great and there is much room for growth.
cons: Constant Emails and repetition get very annoying.

review_title: Good atmosphere, very poor research laboratories
pros: Managers are very nice and the work place is peaceful
cons: The facilities are old and not very comfortable

job_title: Pots&Pans, Receiver?Utility Worker in Washington, DC
pros: Great co-workers in the overall positions.
cons: They will not match the monetary amount you put into the 401k, and will not donate anything towards ut at all!

job_title: Tech Services Employee in Washington, DC
pros: Great co-workers, middle management is very friendly, pay is decent for a college student.
cons: Other administrations might get in the way; poor communication between departments.

pros: Some nice people, some good benefits
cons: Presidential overreach/micro-management.  Any significant promotion seem to be for political vs. actual competency.  Happens at a lot of universities, but this seemed extreme

review_title: Decent money but very variable bosses
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Flexible hours, good effective hourly rate
cons: Some professors treat their research assistants very well, others are disorganized, unrealistic in expectations, and pass off their RA's work as their own

pros: Best community ever, nice facilities, and very good professors. Also, cua has the ideal campus ever; it's so beautiful.
cons: Rush hour time in the area

pros: Great atmosphere, the people are amazing.  Passion and love of the school are qualities every employee holds.
cons: Athletic facilities are dated - lack of monetary resources.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Very easy, laid back, you can do homework while working
cons: Too many lazy employees who would not even do the bare minimum

review_title: I do recommend to work here
pros: Friendly people, working environment is nice,people are willing to help each other
cons: pay could be a little better, the university needs more diversity,

pros: Benefits and work environment positive
